metadata.subject: NATIONAL DEFENSE: IS ANOTHER SPENDING BOOM ON THE HORIZON?
metadata.sender: Joseph G. Carson, US Economist and Director—Global Economic Research

organizations: US House Committee on Oversight and Accountability
financial_entities: Hong Kong Securities and Futures Commission

relationships.description: Both support increased defense spending, with McCain proposing an even more aggressive plan
Carson is US Economist and Director of Global Economic Research at AllianceBernstein

analysis.purpose: To analyze the potential economic impact of proposed defense spending increases under the Trump administration
analysis.significance: Provides economic analysis of potential defense spending boom and its inflationary implications during early Trump presidency

notable_quotes: Trump's military expenditures could be at the low end of what some in Congress are proposing.
A large multi-year defense-spending program would definitely lift inflationary pressures.
We're coming off the weakest five-year defense spending trend in the past 50 years.

blackmail_indicators.description: No indicators of blackmail or coercion found in this economic analysis report

illegal_activity.description: This is an economic analysis report with no illegal activity discussed or evidenced

public_knowledge.context: Economic analysis of defense spending proposals during Trump administration transition period

analysis.summary: This economic analysis report examines the potential for increased defense spending under the Trump administration, comparing it to historical defense buildups and assessing the potential inflationary impacts on the US economy. The report notes similarities to the 1960s economic environment and suggests defense spending increases could add 100-200 basis points to inflation.
